title: K. C. Jones
text:
K. C. Jones (May 25, 1932 – December 25, 2020) was an American professional <a href="basketball">basketball</a> player and coach. He is best known for his association with the <a href="Boston%20Celtics">Boston Celtics</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> (NBA), with whom he won 11 of his 12 <a href="NBA%20championship">NBA championship</a>s (eight as a player, one as an assistant coach, and two as a head coach). As a player, he is tied for third for most NBA championships in a career, and is one of three NBA players with an 8–0 record in NBA Finals series. He is the only African-American coach other than <a href="Bill%20Russell">Bill Russell</a> to have won multiple NBA championships. Jones was inducted into the <a href="Naismith%20Memorial%20Basketball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame</a> in 1989.
Early life.
Jones was born in <a href="Taylor%2C%20Texas">Taylor, Texas</a>, as the oldest of six children. The initials "K. C." were his given name; he inherited the same name as his father, a factory worker and cook, who himself was named after the fabled railroad engineer <a href="Casey%20Jones">Casey Jones</a>. When Jones was aged nine, his parents divorced and he moved to <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco, California</a>, with his mother and two siblings. He learned to play basketball on a patch of gravel.
Jones attended Commerce High School in San Francisco where he played basketball and <a href="American%20football">football</a>.
Playing career.
Jones played <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20San%20Francisco">University of San Francisco</a> and, along with <a href="Bill%20Russell">Bill Russell</a>, guided the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Dons%20men%27s%20basketball">Dons</a> to <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a> championships in 1955 and 1956. During their time with the Dons, Russell and Jones led the team to a then-record 55-game win streak (including an undefeated 29–0 record during the <a href="1955%E2%80%9356%20NCAA%20men%27s%20basketball%20season">1955–56 season</a>) and helped pioneer a play that later became known as the <a href="Alley-oop%20%28basketball%29">alley-oop</a>.
Jones also played with Russell on <a href="1956%20United%20States%20men%27s%20Olympic%20basketball%20team">the United States national team</a> which won the gold medal at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201956%20Summer%20Olympics">1956 Olympic Games</a> in <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, Australia, while defeating their opponents by an unsurpassed average margin of 53.5 points per game.
After completing college and joining the NBA, Jones considered a career as an <a href="NFL">NFL</a> player, even trying out for a team. However, he failed to make the cut. During his playing days, he was known as a tenacious defender. Jones spent all of his nine seasons in the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a> with the <a href="Boston%20Celtics">Boston Celtics</a>, being part of <a href="List%20of%20NBA%20players%20with%20most%20championships">eight championship teams</a> from 1959 to 1966, retiring after the Celtics' loss to the <a href="Philadelphia%2076ers">Philadelphia 76ers</a> in the 1967 Eastern Division Finals. He was inducted into the <a href="Naismith%20Memorial%20Basketball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame</a> in 1989.
Jones is one of only eight players in basketball history to have won an NCAA championship, an NBA championship, and an Olympic gold medal, joining <a href="Bill%20Russell">Bill Russell</a>, <a href="Magic%20Johnson">Magic Johnson</a>, <a href="Michael%20Jordan">Michael Jordan</a>, <a href="Jerry%20Lucas">Jerry Lucas</a>, <a href="Clyde%20Lovellette">Clyde Lovellette</a>, <a href="Quinn%20Buckner">Quinn Buckner</a>, and <a href="Anthony%20Davis">Anthony Davis</a>. In NBA history, only his former teammates Russell (11 championships) and <a href="Sam%20Jones%20%28basketball%2C%20born%201933%29">Sam Jones</a> (10) have won more championships during their playing careers.
Coaching career.
Jones began his coaching career at <a href="Brandeis%20University">Brandeis University</a>, serving as its head coach from 1967 to 1970. He served as an assistant coach at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> from 1970 to 1971. Jones then reunited with former teammate <a href="Bill%20Sharman">Bill Sharman</a> as the assistant coach for the 1971–72 NBA champion <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Lakers">Los Angeles Lakers</a>. During that season, the team won a record 33 straight games. He became the first-ever head coach of the <a href="American%20Basketball%20Association">ABA</a>'s <a href="San%20Diego%20Conquistadors">San Diego Conquistadors</a> on August 8, 1972.
One week after Jones' only season with the Conquistadors ended with his resignation, he signed a three‐year contract to succeed <a href="Gene%20Shue">Gene Shue</a> in a similar capacity with the <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Capital%20Bullets%20season">Capital Bullets</a> (name changed to <a href="Washington%20Wizards">Washington Bullets</a> beginning in <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Washington%20Bullets%20season">1974–75</a>) on June 18, 1973. During his three years in Washington, the Bullets had a 155–91 win‐loss record and arguably the most talented team in the league. Being swept by the <a href="Golden%20State%20Warriors">Golden State Warriors</a> in the <a href="1975%20NBA%20Finals">1975 NBA Finals</a> and a seven-game loss to the <a href="Cleveland%20Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a> in the <a href="1976%20NBA%20playoffs">Eastern Conference Semifinals the following year</a> resulted in Jones' contract not being renewed on May 7, 1976. He was replaced by <a href="Dick%20Motta">Dick Motta</a> three weeks later on May 28, 1976.
In 1983, Jones took over as head coach of the Boston Celtics, replacing <a href="Bill%20Fitch">Bill Fitch</a>. Jones guided the <a href="Larry%20Bird">Larry Bird</a>-led Celtics to championships in 1984 and 1986. Also in 1986, Jones led the Eastern squad in the <a href="1986%20NBA%20All-Star%20Game">1986 NBA All-Star Game</a> in <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a> at the <a href="Reunion%20Arena">Reunion Arena</a>, beating the Western squad 139–132. The Celtics won the <a href="Atlantic%20Division%20%28NBA%29">Atlantic Division</a> in all five of Jones's seasons as head coach and reached the NBA Finals in four of his five years as coach. In a surprise announcement, he retired after the 1987–88 season and was succeeded by assistant coach <a href="Jimmy%20Rodgers%20%28basketball%29">Jimmy Rodgers</a>. Jones spent one season in the Celtics' front office in 1988–89, then resigned to join the <a href="Seattle%20SuperSonics">Seattle SuperSonics</a> as an assistant coach and basketball consultant for the 1989–90 season. He served as head coach of the Sonics in 1990–91 and 1991–92.
In 1994, Jones joined the <a href="Detroit%20Pistons">Detroit Pistons</a> as an assistant coach for one season. The Pistons' head coach at that time, <a href="Don%20Chaney">Don Chaney</a>, had previously played for Jones with the Celtics. Jones was also considered to once again coach the Celtics during the off-season in 1995. In 1996, Jones returned to the Boston Celtics, this time as an assistant coach for one season.
Jones returned to the professional coaching ranks in 1997, guiding the <a href="New%20England%20Blizzard">New England Blizzard</a> of the fledgling women's <a href="American%20Basketball%20League%20%281996%E2%80%931998%29">American Basketball League</a> (1996–1998) through its last 1½ seasons of existence. The Blizzard made the playoffs in his second year as head coach, but they were summarily dispatched by the <a href="San%20Jose%20Lasers">San Jose Lasers</a>.
Personal life.
Jones married Beverly Cain – the sister of his Olympic teammate <a href="Carl%20Cain">Carl Cain</a> – in 1959; they had five children together before they divorced. He had a sixth child when he remarried to Ellen. His son, Kipper, played as a guard at <a href="Bentley%20College">Bentley College</a>. His daughter, Bryna, received a basketball and volleyball scholarship to attend the <a href="University%20of%20Hawaii">University of Hawaii</a>.
Death.
Jones died on December 25, 2020, at an assisted living center in Connecticut, aged 88. He had <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's disease</a>.
